contentrichtext.text: {{Other uses|Ring (disambiguation){{!}}Ring}} A '''ring''' [[diacritic]] may appear above or below letters. It may be combined with some [[Letter (alphabet)|letters]] of the extended [[Latin alphabet]]s in various contexts. {{Diacritical marks|{{unicode|˚}}|caption=Ring}} {{Letters with ring}} ==Ring above== In Unicode, the above encoding is: {{unichar|030A|COMBINING RING ABOVE|html=|cwith=◌}}. Though the [[Danish language|Danish]], [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]] and [[Walloon language|Walloon]] character [[Å]] (å) is derived from an [[A]] with a ring, it is considered a distinct [[letter (alphabet)|letter]] in those languages. The letter Å is the symbol of the unit [[ångström]], named after the Swedish physicist [[Anders Jonas Ångström]]. The character Ů (ů; a Latin [[U]] with ring above, or [[wiktionary:kroužek|kroužek]] in Czech) is a [[grapheme]] in the [[Czech language]] preserved for historic reasons, which identifies a [[vowel shift]]. For example, the word for "horse" used to be written ''kóň'', which evolved, along with pronunciation, into ''kuoň''. Ultimately, the vowel [o] disappeared completely, and the ''uo'' evolved into ''ů'', modern form ''kůň''. The letter ''ů'' now has the same pronunciation as the letter ''[[ú]]'' (long {{IPA|[uː]}}), but changes to a short ''o'' when a word is morphed (e.g. nom. ''[[:wikt:kůň|kůň]]'' → gen. ''koně'', nom. ''dům'' → gen. ''domu''), thus showing the historical evolution of the language. ''Ů'' cannot occur in initial position, however, ''ú'' occurs almost exclusively in initial position or at the beginning of a word [[Root (linguistics)|root]] in a compound. These characters are used also in [[Silesian language|Steuer's Silesian alphabet]]. The [uo] pronunciation has prevailed in some [[Moravian language|Moravian]] dialects, as well as in the [[Slovak language]], which uses the letter [[ô]] instead of ů. The ring is also used in [[Bolognese dialect|Bolognese]] (a dialect of [[Emiliano-Romagnolo language]]) to distinguish the sound {{IPA|/ɑ/}} (å) from {{IPA|/a/}} (a). The ring has been used in the [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] [[Cyrillic]] alphabet promoted by Russian authorities in the last quarter of 19th century with the letter {{Unicode|У̊}} / {{Unicode|у̊}} used to represent the {{IPA|/wɔ/}} diphthong (now written ''uo'' in Lithuanian orthography). Ring upon e (e̊) is used by certain [[dialectologist]]s of [[Walloon language]] (especially [[:wa:Jean-Jacques Gaziaux|Jean-Jacques Gaziaux]]) to note the /ə/ vowel typically replacing /i/ and /y/ in the [[Walloon Brabant|Brabant province]] central Walloon dialects. The difficulty of type-writing it has led some writers to prefer ''ë'' for the same sound. Many more characters can be created in [[Unicode]] using the "combining ring above" U+030A, including the above mentioned {{Unicode|у̊}} (Cyrillic у with ring above) or even {{Unicode|ń̊}} (n with acute and ring above). The [[Modifier letter ring above|standalone ring above]] symbol has the codepoint U+02DA. ==Ring below== [[Unicode]] encodes the ring below at {{unichar|0325|COMBINING RING BELOW|cwith=◌}} The diacritic is used in [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] to indicate [[Voice (phonetics)|voicelessness]], and in [[Indo-European studies]] or in [[Sanskrit]] transliteration ([[IAST]]) to indicate [[syllabic consonant|syllabicity]] of r, l, m, n etc. (e.g. {{PIE|r̥}} corresponding to IPA {{IPA|[ɹ̩]}}). Examples: * {{unichar|1E00|LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A WITH RING BELOW}} * {{unichar|1E01|LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH RING BELOW}} ==Half rings== Half rings also exist as diacritic marks, these are characters {{unichar|0351|combining left half ring above|cwith=◌}} and {{unichar|0357|combining left half ring below|cwith=◌}}. These characters may be used in the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]], denoting [[roundedness]]. They are here given with the lowercase a: {{Unicode|a͑}} and {{Unicode|a͗}}. Other, similar signs are in use in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]: the {{unichar|0559|left half ring above|cwith=◌}}, and the [[comma (punctuation)|Armenian comma]] or {{unichar|055A|right half ring above|cwith=◌}}. The ring as a diacritic mark should not be confused with the [[Dot (diacritic)|dot above]] or [[comma (punctuation)|comma above]] diacritic marks, with the combining ''o'' above {{unichar|0366|COMBINING LATIN SMALL LETTER O|cwith=◌}}, or with the degree sign °. ==External links== *[http://diacritics.typo.cz Diacritics Project — All you need to design a font with correct accents] {{Latin alphabet||ring}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ring (Diacritic)}} [[Category:Alphabetic diacritics]]
